bib.title: Klaus Stopp collection of printed Fraktur birth and baptismal certificates.
bib.author: Stopp, Klaus,

subfield.#text: Klaus Stopp collection of printed Fraktur birth and baptismal certificates.
Printed birth and baptismal certificates of the German Americans

Organized by corresponding entry number in "The printed birth and baptismal certificates of the German American" which lists primarily by printer and then by state (starting with Pennsylvania, and then alphabetically) and then chronologically. Variations on printings receive a separate subordinate decimal number. Box  40 contains additions which corresponds to volume 7.

Collection of approximately 1350 printed variants of German American birth and baptismal certificates from about 1700 through 1900; collected and owned by Klaus Stopp and used to create his 7 volume bibliography: The printed birth and baptismal certificated of the German American. Mainz, Germany, K. Stopp, 1997-2014. v. 1-v. 7. Most have completed genealogical information and many are hand colored.
Box 1 and 2 contain information files including photocopies, photographs, transparencies, notes (manuscript and typed), and dealer descriptions/auction catalogs pretaining to the collection.
Printed birth and baptismal certificates of the German Americans.
Council on Library and Information Resources (CLIR) cataloging grant for Wing Foundation Collection, 2013
Complete gospels of Matthew, Mark, Luke, and John with prefaces (Matthew's lacking), tables, and subscriptions.
Collation: 26 gatherings of 8 leaves, gathering 27 has 3 leaves.
Headings and initials in gold; text in brown ink, canons and lessons in red.
A painted miniature of each evangelist in 6 colors on gold background introduces each gospel.
Ricci, S. de,  Census of medieval and renaissance mss.,
Mitchell, E.C.  Critical handbook of the Greek New Testament,
Available on microfilm at the Newberry Library.
In box with title: The Newberry gospels.
Provenance: from the collection of Henry Probasco, who obtained it from Quaritch (Catalogue, 1868. No. 9630, p.657).
Red morocco binding, stamped in gold; signed F. Bedford.
Illumination of books and manuscripts, Medieval

1. fol. 1r: "(addition 14th century) Benedictione perpetua ... Unigenitus dei filius ... Spiritus sancti gratia ... Deus pater omnipotens ... Per evangelica dicta ... Verba sancti evangelii ..." Benedictions for the lessons of the Divine Office.

2. fol. 1v: "(addition 13th century) Infrascripte indulgentie date sunt a diversis summis pontificibus in locis fratrum minorum ..." Obituary notes and a recipe added by later hands, approximately 1300.

3. fol. 2r: "(addition 13th century) Hec sunt festa que secundum decretales et decreta debent obseruari ... Et illa festa que singuli episcopi in suis episcopatibus cim clero et populo collaudauerint celebranda, sicut Perusii festum sancti Erculani et Constantii."

4. fol. 2r: "(addition 13th century) Nota quod secundum Augustinum est visio triplex quarum quelibet dicitur celum scilicet corporalis, ymaginaria et intellecualis ... tertio modo Paulus." Unidentified extract of scholastic distinctions.

5. fol. 2r-2v: "(addition 13th century) Mclxxxxiiii foro scarepate [?] le rocche da Sese ..." A brief chronicle of Perugia in Italian and Latin with entries by at least two hands; last entry 1289, records entry of Friar Bartholus Blancellus to the order of friars (autograph).

6. fol. 2v: "(addition after 1266) Viiio kalendas ianuarii luna. Anno Cesaris Augusti quadragesimo secundo, ebdimada iuxta Danielis prophetiam sexagesima sexta olympiade autem centesima et nonagesima tertia, sextam mundi etatem, suo piissimo consecrans adventu Ihesus Christus filius dei vivi in Bethleem nascitur ... Et alibi aliorum plurimorum sanctorum martirum confessorum atque virginum." Martyrology entry for Christmas Eve in accordance with the statutes of the chapter of Paris (1266).
7. fol. 3r: "(addition 13th century) Gaude virgo prophetata patriarchis figurata supernali radio ..." fol. 3v: blank.
8. fol. 4r-29v: Liturgical Psalter. This section without musical notation. Numerous marginal corrections, 13th-14th century.

9. fol. 29v-30v: Daily canticles, Te Deum, Pater noster. Credo in deum, patrem omnipotentem, creatorem ceil et terre ..., Gloria in excelsis deo ..., Credo in unum deum, patrem omnipotentem, factorem celi et terre ..., Quicumque vult saluus esse ... Leroquais."
11. fol. 31v-33v: Calendar of the Roman court, approximately 1230.
12. fol. 34r-164r: "[rubr.] In nomine domini. Incipit ordo breviarii fratrum minorum secundum consuetudinem romane curie ... [text]."
13. fol. 164r: "[rubr.] In omnibus festiuitatibus que in sabbatis ... et tertio nonas eiusdem mansis."

14. fol. 164r-215v: "[rubr.] Incipiunt festiuitates sanctorum per totum annum. In festo sancti Saturnini ... [text]" Proper of Saints, Saturninus through Francis. Ends with nine lessons for the feast of Francis.
15. fol. 216r-216v: "(addition 14th century) [rubr.] In festo sancte Helisabet ..."
16. fol. 216v-217r: "(addition 14th century) [rubr.] In sancte Caterine virginis et martiris oratio." Collect and nine lessons for the feast of Catherine of Alexandria.
17. fol. 217r-218v: "(addition 14th century) [rubr.] In festo sancte Clare virginis ... [text]."
18. fol. 218v-219v: "(addition 14th century) [rubr.] In festo niuis sancte Marie ...[text]."

19. fol. 219v-226v: "(addition 14th century) Franciscus primus dictus est Iohannes ... omnis sit laus primus dictus est Iohannes ... omnis sit laus honor et gloria in secula seculorum. Amen." Division of lessons, content notes, and corrections noted in outer margings.

20. fol. 226v-227v: "(addition 14th century) In festo translationis (in margin). Franciscus igitur seruus et amicus ... mirificans sanctum suum magnificentia virtutis altissimi, cui est honor et gloria per infinita secula seculorum. Amen." Division of lessons written in margin.
21. fol. 228r-236r: "In festo sanctorum martirum Sergi et Bachi ..." Proper of Saints, conclusion.
23. fol. 249v-250r: "[rubr.] Incipit officium beate Marie virginis secundum consuetudinem romane curie ..."
24. fol. 250r: "[rubr.] Duplex officium agitur in nativitate domini ... et basilicarum Petri et Pauli."
25. fol. 250r-251v: "Regem cui omnia viunt ..." Pre-Haymonian Office of the Dead.
26. fol. 251v-252r: "[rubr.] Ordo minorum secundum consuetudinem romane ecclesie ad visitandum infirmum ..."
29. fol. 253v-256v: Ten different settings for Psalm 94, Venite exultemus ...
30. fol. 257r: (addition 13th century) Notes for or extracts from a biblical concordance.
31. fol. 257v: "(addition 13th century) Isti sunt modi dilatandi sermones qui sunt viii. Primus modus, ponendo ... contemplatiua et actiua, fides et spes." Extensive marginal commentary.
32. fol. 258r: "(addition 14th century) Ave verum corpus natum de Maria virgine ..." Salutation to the Virgin for two voices.
33. fol. 258v: "(addition 14th century) In festo beati Antonii ..." Three hymns for the Office of the Feast of Anthony of Padua.

34. fol. 259r: "(addition 14th century) Reminiscens beati sanguinis quem profudit amator hominis profundo lacrimas ... Ave vivens hostia veritas et vita in quo sacrificia ... Prosa in resurrectione domini. Qui se ipsum immolauit pro delictis omnium ... ut perducat et inducat ad suam celi gloriam. Amen."

35. fol. 259v-260r: "(addition 14th century) De sermone sancti Augustini in festo nativitatis domine (in margin). Denique post illius benedicibilis presagium ... sit tibi assidue exorare pro popula dei que meruisti benedicta pretium offerre mundi, qui vivit et regnat in secula seculorum. Amen."

36. fol. 260r: "(addition 14th century) De officio misse (in margin). Nota quod beatus Iacobus frater domini et Basilius cesariensis videntur tradidisse ordinem dicendi missam ... sine stola et manipulo di. 21 ecclesiastica."

37. fol. 260v-264r: "(addition 14th century) Incipit officium sacratissimi corporis Ihesu Christi (in margin). Sacerdos in eternum ..." Office of Corpus Christi established by the General Chapter of Marseille (1319) as modified by the General Chapter of Cahors (1338) cited in note in lower margin, fol. 260v. Many marginal additions.
38. fol. 246v-265r: "(addition 14th century) In festo beati Antonii ..." Office for the Feast of Anthony of Padua as established by the General Chapter of Toulouse.

39. fol. 265v-266v: "(addition 14th century) Legenda beati Ludouici episcopi (in margin). Iohannes episcopus ... [ends imperfectly at the end of the leaf] deseruit totaliter et contempsit. Nam" Bull of canonization of Louis, Bishop of Toulouse, divided by marginal index notes into lessons.

40. fol. 266v: "(addition 14th century in lower margin) Totius vite ipsius beati Ludouici decursus fuit ... Anno incarnationis dominice mo ccco xvio septimo idus aprilis papa Johannes XXIIus  ... sanctorum cathalogo cum maximis sollempniis in civitate Avinionis ubi tunc romana curia residebat, ascribi fecit." Martyrology entry for Louis Toulouse.

Collation: Parchment, fol. 266 (error in foliation: fol. 175 should be 176); 1⁴(-1) 2¹² 3⁶ 4¹² 5-6¹⁰ 7¹² 8-22¹⁰ 23¹² 24-26¹⁰ 27¹⁰(-10); catchwords occasionally enclosed in rectangles present for the original book only beginning with quire 5.

Layout: Psalter written in 47 lines is two columns, remainder of the original book in 63 lines in two columns; Quires 2-3, prickings visible in outer margins; quires 5-22 and 24-26, prickings visible in lower margins; ruled in plummet.

Script: Witten in Italian gothic textualis media by at least two hands, beginning below the first ruled line; script characterized by a trailing terminal "s"; addtions in quire 23 in Italian gothic textualis media with one-story "a," long "s" slightly below the line; quire 27 written in a similar script characterized by regular use of long termial "s."
Origin: Written in Italy before or about 1230; inclusion of Dominic (canonized 1232) on fol. 86v is a correction; quires 2-4 written approximately 1260.

Decoration: fol. 5-22, 26: Alternating red and blue initials with an occasional black initial; capitals touched in red; fol. 2-4, 23 have red and blue flourished and alternating minor red and blue simple initials; fol. 27 has red initials only with black paragraph marks.
Saenger, P.  Cat. of pre-1500 western manuscript books,
Ricci, S. de. Census of medieval and Renaissance manuscripts in the United States and Canada,
Dijk, S. J. P. van "Some manuscripts of the earliest Franciscan Liturgy." In Franciscan Studies, v. 16, no. 1/2 (1956),
Hughes, A.  Medieval manuscripts for mass and office,
Probasco, H.  Catalogue of the collection of books, manuscripts, and works of art, belonging to Mr. Henry Probasco, Cincinnati, Ohio, (Oakwood, Clifton.),
Microfilm available at the Newberry Library.
Acquired from the collection of Henry Probasco;

In Franciscan convent of Perugia in the second half of the 13th century; quire 1 added at this time with texts and notes written by Friar Bartholus Blancellus on fol. 1v-2v; additions to litany and calendar of Perugian saints.
Quires 23 and 26 added in the 14th century; fol. 257v, and erased ex libris illegible under ultraviolet light; fol. 226v, an erased number (16th century?), possibly a shelf-mark.
Number 8 from the collection of Henry Probasco.

In blind-tooled calf, probably 18th century. Binding described in Saenger catalog "Bound in geometrically ruled olive morocco binding, Italian, possibaly Venetian, approximately 1700" and described in Probasco catalog as "vellum binding, old and worm-eaten".
Cataloged from existing description: Saenger, P.  Cat. of pre-1500 western manuscript books.

cataloging_level.@desc: Default Level for Bib Records--any cataloger may edit

subfield.#text: 1. fol. 1r-120v: "[fol. 5r, in violet] Beatissimo patri Allexandrini quinto pontifici maximo Iacobus Angelus. [text] [A]d tempora Claudii et [sic] Ptolomei viri allexandrini ... [fol. 6r, in violet] Claudii Ptholomeii cosmographie liber primus habet [text] .. [C]osmographia designatrix imitatio est totius cognitit orbis ... versus boream usque ad utrosque polos zodiaci. [in violet] Claudii Ptolomei viri allexandrini cosmografie octauus et ultimus liber explicit et cetera." fol. 1r-4v and 117r-120v: blank.
2. fol. 121r-121v: Geometrically drawn astronomical diagram. fol. 121v: blank.

3. fol. 122r-123v: "[C]uiuslibet arcus propositi sinum rectum inuenire ... [fol. 122v] et duplicatum est arcus istius corde." Additions of 15th century ex. and two tables of Johannes de Lineriis follow.

4. fol. 129r-130r: "[H]oc instrumentum factum est pro inueniendo gradum ascendentium dicitur itaque ... [fol. 129v] paulo minus et cetera. Prima domus uitam censem notat inde secunda, tercia germanos ... cuique modum seruare suis uelod infrascriptum[?] altis[?]."

5. fol. 130v-134v: [additions 16th century] "Omina [sic] igitur instrumentorum sunt hec, primum est armilla suspenssoria ad capiendum altitudinem ... tabule autem ab hac signate sunt hec." fol. 131r-134v: blank.

6. fol. 135r-141r: "[C]irculus ecentricus dicitur vel egresse cuspidius vel eggredientis centri ... de reflexione est gradus [?] 1 in minuta 4 et cetera. Et sicut est finis laudetur deus et sanctus Bartholomeus." Astronomical summary composed by Gerard of Sabbioneta which has often been ascribed to Gerard of Cremona. Later scholarship finds this attribution still uncertain, though the authorship of Gerard of Cremona and the others has generally been rejected; see e.g. Olaf Pedersen, "The origins of the Theorica planetarum", in Journal for the history of astronomy, 12 (1981), p. 113-123.
7. fol. 141v-142v: Astronomical diagrams of the eclipse of the sun and moon. fol. 142r-142v: blank.
8. fol. 143r-144v: Astronomical diagram, 16th century. fol. 143r-144v: blank.

9. fol. 145r-149v: [addition, approximately 1500] "Ad probamdum [sic] circa quamlibet speciem numeri utrum bene operatum fuerit utendum est hoc modo generali ... [fol. 147r] Quadratum circulo circumscriptum habet se in proportione ad circulum scriptum sicut 14 ad ii ... 3m et divide per primum." Unidentified scientific text. fol. 148r-149v: blank.

10. fol. 150r-155v: "Tractatus de fluxu et refluxu aque maris. Secundum Aristotelem 4o [sic] metheororum de his que sunt manifesta sensui putamus sufficienter demonstrasse ... quare nec motus aquatum ita certo incedunt ordine. Hec de diversis motibus aque maris opinione Iacobi de Dundis Padauii ciuis et ecplicit tractatus de diversis motibus accessus et recessus aque maris compilatus a magistro Iacobo de Dundis."
11. fol. 151v-159v: Diagrams of the tides, 16th century. fol. 156v-159v: blank.

Collation: Paper (watermarks of monts and licorne, not in Briquet), fol. 159; 1⁴ 2-12¹⁰ 13¹⁰(8-10 missing) 14⁴(+1) 15-16⁸ 17⁸ (unidentified leaf missing) 18⁶ 19⁴; leaves signed in at least three sequences; catchwords for text 1 within rectangular decoration, sometimes touched with violet.

Layout: fol. 5r-116v written in 35 lines two columns; fol. 122r-122v written in 40 lines, this and following portion only beginning on the first ruled line; fol. 129r-130r written in 44 lines in two columns; fol. 135-141 written in 44 long lines; fol. 150r-155v written in about 35 long lines; ruled in hard point, lead point, and pen.

Script: fol. 5r-116v written in Italian hybrida media; fol. 122r-122v: written in Italian hybrida media; fol. 129r-130r written in Italian hybrida currens; fol. 135r-141r written in Italian hybrida media with trailing terminal "s"; fol. 150r-155v written in Italian hybrida media; fol. 5r-16r, 122r-122v, and 158r-156r all by one scribe, in brown in now eating into the paper; all other texts written by a different hand for each.
Origin: Written in Italy in the middle of the 15th century.
Saenger, P.  Cat. of pre-1500 western manuscript books,
Butler, R.L.  Check list of the mss. in the Ayer Coll.,
Ricci, S. de. Medieval and Renaissance mss.,

Provenance: Fol. 5, "Yhesus Maria," written below a hollow pen cross, touched with violet; fol. 1, "Cosmographia Claudii Tholomei," written by an Italian hand, 17-18th century; below, a circular white sticker, partially removed, with "⁰38" (?) written in black ink; "CHJ" written in black in in the lower inner corner on the verso of the last leaf.
Formerly in the Ptolemy Collection of Henry Stevens.
Forms part of the Edward E. Ayer Manuscript Collection (Newberry Library)
Binding: In gold-stamped black morocco in the second half of the 19th century by W. Pratt; the name of binder given on the bookplate of Edward E. Ayer.
Also available online via Internet Archive.
Edward E. Ayer Manuscript Collection (Newberry Library)
Full text of Newberry Library's copy in Internet Archive

bib.title: [Manuscript portolan atlas of the Mediterranean Sea]
bib.author: Giroldi, Giacomo,

subfield.#text: [Manuscript portolan atlas of the Mediterranean Sea]

Unsigned atlas attributed to the Venetian portolan maker Giacomo Giroldi in Akerman, James. "From books with maps to books as maps: the editor in the creation of the atlas idea" in Editing early and historical atlases ... / ed. by Joan Winearls (Toronto: University of Toronto Press, 1995) p. 5-7, 15-16, and 38, note 6.

[Chart of the Adriatic Sea] -- [Chart of northwestern Africa, the Canary Islands, Gibraltar, and the Iberian Peninsula] -- [Chart of the British Isles and western Europe between the Netherlands and northern Spain] -- [Chart of the central Mediterranean Sea] -- [Chart of the eastern Mediterranean Sea] -- [Chart of the Black Sea and the Sea of Marmara].

Pen-and-ink and paint (red, green, brown, yellow, blue). Vellum charts pasted back-to-back within contemporary binding of wood boards covered with stamped leather (triangles within rectangles, double-ruled).

For list of Giroldi's works see Campbell, Tony. "Portolan charts from the late thirteenth century to 1500" in The History of Cartography / ed. by Harley and Woodward (Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 1987) v. 1, p. 452-453.

Unidentified dealer's description trimmed from a printed catalog and pasted inside back cover: "A very antient map of the world, folded in canvas, within boarded covers, of the fifteenth century, upon vellum, folio."
Owned by Thomas Phillipps: "957 MSS. Phillipps" above the stamped crest and initials of Phillipps on verso of last leaf.

Description from Catalogue of geography, voyages, travels, history of America, Africa, Australasia and Asia ... (London: [Bernard Quaritch], 1899), catalogue 188, p. 113, no. 906 pasted inside front cover. "Quaritch 1902. £25.00" in pencil on first leaf.
Forms part of the Edward E. Ayer Manuscript Map Collection (Newberry Library).
Smith, C.A. List of ms. maps Ayer Coll.,
Edward E. Ayer Manuscript Map Collection (Newberry Library)

bib.title: Incipit tractatus m[a]g[ist]ri Joh[ann]is de Gersonno eximii p[ro]fesso[r]is sacre theologie de t[ri]bulatio[n]ib[us] ex def[ec]tuoso ecc[lesi]astico[rum] regimi[n]e ad[huc] ecc[lesia]e p[er]iu[r]turis et de signis eoru[m]de[m] /
bib.author: Gerson, Jean,

subfield.#text: Incipit tractatus m[a]g[ist]ri Joh[ann]is de Gersonno eximii p[ro]fesso[r]is sacre theologie de t[ri]bulatio[n]ib[us] ex def[ec]tuoso ecc[lesi]astico[rum] regimi[n]e ad[huc] ecc[lesia]e p[er]iu[r]turis et de signis eoru[m]de[m] /
ex s[er]mone p[ro]nu[n]ciato de [con]ceptio[n]e ui[r]ginis in consilio constantiensi,
Tractatus magistri Johannis de Gersonno eximii professoris sacre theologie de tribulationibus ex defectuoso ecclesiasticorum regimine adhuc ecclesiae periurturis et de signis eorumdem
De tribulationibus ex defectuoso ecclesiasticorum regimine adhuc ecclesiae periurturis et de signis eorumdem
First printed in Gerson's Opera of 1488.

Ms. copy, probably transcribed around 1450, possibly in France, of a portion of a sermon delivered by Jean Gerson at the Council of Constance, held in Konstanz, Germany between 1414 and 1418, on the corruption and failures of ecclesiastical government and life, and the need for reform.

Text in brown ink, 37 lines per page, with large initial and underlining in red; smaller capitals touched in red throughout; bounding lines blind-ruled with a stylus or other sharp instrument; edges stained red.

bib.title: A leaf from the Gutenberg Bible : Ezekiel 37:11 to 39:7.
bib.author: Gutenberg, Johann,

subfield.#text: A leaf from the Gutenberg Bible :

Accompanying text describes leaf as acquired and sold by the Scribner Book Store in 1953. Originally part of an imperfect copy found in a peasant's hut in Olewig, near Trier by the librarian Wyttenbach.
Forms part of the Rudy Lamont Ruggles Collection at the Newberry Library.

1. fol. 1r-7v: Calendar in violet and black with major feasts in red encompassing a mixture of English and Flemish saints, all in the usual Bruges format of six folios. Feasts include Sancti Uulfranni episcopi (January 19, in red), Baltildis virginis (January 30), Sancti Blasii episcopi (February 3), Cathedra Petri (February 21, in red), Sancti Edwardi regis (March 18), Sancti Dunstani archiepiscopi (May 19), Translatio Edmunti episcopi (June 9), Sancti Kenelmi martiris (July 17), Sancti Ozwaldi regis (August 5), Sancte Cutburge virginis (August 31), Egidii abbatis (September 1), Sancti Cutberthi episcopi (September 4), Remigii et Bauonis (October 1, in red), Sancti Hugonis episcopi (November 17), Sancti Edmundi regis (November 20), Grisogonii martiris (November 24). Translation of Thomas à Becket on July 7 and his feast on December 28 erased. In upper lines of calendar, Latin month verses, "Prima dies mensis et septima trucat ut ensis ..." fol. 7r: blank and unruled; 7v: miniature for following text.

2. fol. 8r-14v: "[in violet] Oratio deuota ad dominum nostrum Ihesum Christum. [text] O domine Ihesu Christe, eterme dulcedo te amancium ... te merear laudare cum omnibus sanctis tuis in eternum. Amen." fol. 14r: blank; fol. 14v: miniature for the following text.

3. fol. 15r-35v: Suffrages of the Saints. "Memoria de sancta trinitate ... Memoria de sancto Iohanne Baptista ... Memoria de sancto Georgio ... Memoria de sancto Christoforo martir ... Memoria de sancto Thoma cantuariensis [rubric and text scratched out, 16th century] ... Memoria de sancta Anna ... Memoria de sancta Maria Magdalena ... Memoria de sancta Catherina ... Memoria de sancta Barbara ... Memoria de sancta Margareta ..." fol. 35r: blank and unruled; fol. 35v: miniature for the following text.

4. fol. 36r-74v: "[in violet] Incipiunt hore beate Marie uirginis secundum consuetudinem Anglie." Hours of the Virgin, use of Salisbury. fol. 48v-53r: after lauds, suffrages to the Holy Spirit, Holy Trinity, the Holy Cross, Michael, John the Baptist, Peter and Paul, Andrew, Stephen, Lawrence, Thomas of Canterbury (crossed out, 16th century), Nicholas, Mary Magdalene, Catherine, Margaret, All Saints, for peace, to the Holy Cross. Hours of the Cross worked in. Office of the Virgin followed by Salue regina and prayer, "Omnipotens sempiterne deus qui gloriose uirginis ..."
5. fol. 74v-75r: "[in violet] Oratio ad Mariam. [text] Gaude, flore uirginali ... sed durabunt et florescent in perhenni gloria."
6. fol. 75v: "Dulcissime domine Ihesu Christe qui beatissimam genitricem tuam ... feliciter peruiamus eterna. Qui uiuis et regnas."
7. fol. 75v-76r: "[in violet] Oratio de domina nostra. [text] Gaude uirgo mater Christi que per aurem concepisti, Gabriele nuntio ... per te detur nobis frui in perhenni uirginem gaudio. Amen."

8. fol. 76r-77v: "[in violet] Oratio. [text] Deus qui beatissimam uirginem Mariam in conceptu et partu uirginitate reseruata duplici gaudio letificasti ... et precibus intercessione ualeamus peruenire. Per Christum dominum nostrum." fol. 76v: blank; fol. 77r: blank and unruled; fol. 77v: miniature for the following text.

9. fol. 78r-82r: "[in violet] Eas uideas laudes qui sacra uirgine gaudes et uenerando piam studeas laudare Mariam uirginis uita eterne cum ueneris ante figuram pretereundo, caue ne taceatur aue inuenies ueniam sic salutando Mariam; Salue. [text] Salue, uirgo uirginum, stella matutina, sordidorum ... in gloria sua collocare in secula seculorum. Amen."
10. fol. 82r: "[in violet] Oratio. [text] Deus qui de beate Marie uirginis utero uerbum tuum ... apud te intercessionibus adiuuemur. Per eundem Christum dominum nostrum. Amen."

11. fol. 82r-83v: "[in violet] Oratio de sancta Maria. [text] O intemerata et in eternum benedicta ... O Iohannes ... Uobis duobus ego miserrimus peccator ... et post huius uite cursum ad gaudia me ducat electorum suorum benignissimus paraclitus."

12. fol. 83v-86v: "[in violet] Item alia oratio ad uirginem Mariam. [text] Obsecro te domina sancta Maria ... Et michi famulo tuo ... Maria, mater dei et misericordie. Amen." fol. 86r: blank and unruled; fol. 86v: miniature for the following text.

13. fol. 87r-89r: "[in violet] Quicumque hec septem gaudia in honore beate Marie uirginis semel in die dixerit [centum dies indulgenciam obtinebit a domino papa Clemente (crossed out, 16th century)] qui hec septem gaudia proprio stilo, composuit. [text] Uirgo templum trinitatis, deus summe bonitatis ... ad eternum gaudium ..."

14. fol. 89r-90v: "Deprecor te sanctissima Maria mater dei pietate plenissima ... intercedas pro me peccatore N. famulo tuo ... uitam et requiem sempiternam. Amen." fol. 90r: blank; fol. 90v: miniature for the following text.
15. fol. 91r-93v: "[in violet] Ad ymaginem domini nostri Ihesu Christi. [text] Omnibus consideratis ... quem Christus eripuit."

15 bis. fol. 93v-94r: "Omnipotens sempiterne deus qui unigenitum filium tuum dominum nostrum Ihesum Christum crucem coronam spineam et quinque uulnera subire ... a peccatorum nostrorum nexibus eorum precibus liberemur. Per ..."

16. fol. 94r-95v: "[in violet] Incipit oratio uenerabilis Bede prebiteri de qua fertur quod cotidie et deuote flexis genibus eam dicens nec dyabolus nec mali homines ei poterint nocere nec sine confessione morietur et per tringinta dies ante obitum suum uidebit gloriosam uirginem Mariam in auxilium sibi preparatem; Oratio septem uerborum domini nostri Ihesu Christi. [text] Domine Ihesu Christe qui septem uerba die ultima uite tue in cruce pendens dixisti ... in regno meo epulari, iocundari et commorari per infinita secula seculorum. Amen." The rubic has been partly effaced by an incompletely removed paper masking sheet, 16th century.

17. fol. 95v-96r: "[in violet] Oratio. [text] Precor te, piissime domine Ihesu Christe, propter eximiam caritatem qua humanum genus dilexisti quando tu rex celestis pendebas in cruce ... propter magnam misericordiam tuam michi tribuere digneris. Amen."

18. fol. 96r-96v: "[in violet] Oratio. [text] Gratias ago tibi domine Ihesu Christe qui uoluisti pro redemptione mundi a iudeis reprobari ... quo perduxisti tecum crucifixum latronem et omnes sanctos et sancti. Qui ..."

19. fol. 97r. "[in violet] Salutationes ad sacrosanctum sacramentum. [text] Aue, domine Ihesu Christe, uerbum patris, filius uirginis ... uera fons amoris pax dulcedo requies nostra uita perhennis. Amen."
20. fol. 97r-97v: "[in violet] Oratio. [text] Aue, principium nostre creationis, aue precium nostre redemptionis ... et concede michi famulo tuo N ... et fideliter accipere merear. Amen."
21. fol. 97v: "[in violet] Ad sacrosanctum sacramentum. [text] Aue, uerum corpus natum de Maria uirgine ... O pie, O Ihesu fili Marie, miserere nobis."
22. fol. 97v-98r: "[in violet] Oratio. [text] Aue caro Christi cara, immolata crucis ara, redemptoris hostia ... fac redemptos luce clara tecum frui gloria. Amen."
23. fol. 98r: "[in violet] Oratio. [text] Anima Christi, sanctidica me; corpus Christi, salua me ... in secula seculorum. Amen."

24. fol. 98r-98v: "[in violet] Cuilibet dicenti hanc orationem inter eleuationem corporis Christi et tercium agnus dei dominus [papa Bonifacius sextus concessit dua milia annorum indulgenciarum (crossed out, 16th century)] ad supplicationem Philippi regis Francie; Oratio [text]. Domine Ihesu Christe qui hanc sacratissimam carnem tuam et pretiosum sanguinem tuum de gloriose uirginis Marie utero ... et ab uniuersis malis presentibus, preteritis et futuris nunc et in euum. Per ..." fol. 99r: blank and unruled; fol. 99v: miniature for the following text.
25. fol. 100r-106v: "[in violet] Incipiunt septem psalmi penitentiales."
26. fol. 106v-108r: "[in violet] Incipiunt xv psalmi." Cues only for psalms 119-139, followed by psalms 131, 132, and 133.

27. fol. 108v-115v: "[in violet] Letania." Chad, Gildard, Cedd "Swichine" and "Burine" among the confessors; Praxedis, Petronilla, Edith, and Afra among the virgins; Thomas of Canterbury erased from among the confessors. Litany proper followed by six short prayers: "Deus cui proprium est ... ; Exaudi, quesumus, domine ...; Omnipotens sempiterne deus qui facis mirabilia ...; Deus qui cartatis dona ...; Ineffabilem misericordiam tuam ...; Pietate tuo quesumus, domine ..." Cua only for "Deus a quo sancta desideria ..." fol. 115r: blank and unruled; fol. 115v: miniature for the following text.
28. fol. 116r-136v: "[in violet] Incipiunt uigilie mortuorum." fol. 136r: blank and unruled; fol. 136r: miniature for the following text.
29. fol. 137r-148v: "[in violet] Incipiunt commendationes animarum." fol. 148r: blank; fol. 149v: miniature for the following text.

30. fol. 147v, 149r-153r: "[in violet] Incipit psalterium de passione domini." Psalms 21-29 and 30, 1-6 with cues only for 22-24, 26, and 29. Followed by the prayer, "Respice, quesumus, domine super hanc familiam tuam ... et crucis subire tormentorum."
31a. fol. 153v: Rubric for the Psalter of Saint Jerome. Traces of paper mask, 16th century.

31b. fol. 154r-155v: "[in violet] Oratio. [text] Suscipere digneris, domine deus omnipotens, istos psalmos consecratos ... per omnia secula seculorum. Amen." fol.154v-155r: blank; fol. 155v: miniature for the following text.
31c. fol. 156r-166r. "[in violet] Incipit psalterium beati Iheronimi."

31d. fol. 166r-166v: "[in violet] Oratio. [text] Omnipotens sempiterne deus clemenciam tuam suppliciter deprecamur ut me famulum tuum. N ... atque defunctis proficiat ad gloriam sempiternam. Per ..." fol. 166v: blank.
Collation: Parchment, fol. iii + 166 + 1 ; collation impracticable ; alphabetical leaf signatures mostly timmed
Layout: Written in 19 long lines, calendar in 33 lines; ruled in violet ink.

1. Decoration: 27 full-page miniatures on inserted leaves accompanied by two different border schemes: Border A: blue, green orange acanthus spray with gold ivy stem frame (English in appearance); Border B: blue, gold, violet acanthus spay with floral decoration including thistles, violets, and strawberries, very similar to the Bruges borders associated with Willem Vrelant. Each border accompanied by initials in matching colors 5 lines high.

2. Decoration: 27 full-page miniatures: fol. 7v, border A (Christ with angles playing music on an instrument beloning to the lute family and a harp on either side); fol. 14v, border B (Gnadenstuhl Trinity); fol. 17v, border B (John the Baptist); fol. 19v, border B (George); fol. 21v, border B (Christopher); fol. 23v, border B (Martyrdom of Thomas à Becket); fol. 25v, border B (Anne,the Virgin and Child); fol. 27v, border B (Mary Magdalene); fol. 29v, border B (Catherine); fol. 31v, border B (Barbara); fol. 33v, border B (Margaret); fol. 35v, border A (Jesus in the Garden of Gethsemane); fol. 42v, border B (Kiss of Judas); fol. 54v, border B (Christ before Pilate); fol. 58v, border B (the Flagellation); fol. 61v, border B (Christ carrying the Cross); fol. 64v, border B (the Crucifixion); fol. 67v, border B (Descent from the Cross); fol. 70v, border B (the Entombment); fol. 77v, border B (the Coronation of the Virgin); fol. 86v, border B (Mary ascending the steps at thte Temple); fol. 90v, border B (Adam and Eve in the Garden below the Arbor Vitae, the devil as a female-headed snake entwined around the tree); fol. 99v, border A (Last Judgement); fol. 115v, border B (funeral service by priests and monks); fol. 136v, border B (God the Father receiving two naked souls); fol. 148v, border B (Man of Sorrows, behind him the instruments of torture); fol. 155v, border B (Jerome at his desk).

3. Decoration: 9 historiated initials 5 lines high: fol. 91r, border B (three crosses); fol.91v, 2 initials, border B (Jesus and the stigmata on right hand accompanied by a bracket left type B border); fol 92r, two initials, border B (stigmata on left hand and the wounds of Christ accompanied by a bracket left type B border); fol. 92v, two initials (stigmata on the left foot and stigmanta on the right foot); fol. 93r, two intials, border B (Pietà and John the Evangelist accompanied by a bracket left type B); fol. 91v, 92r, 92v, 93r bracketed left border of type B.

4. Decoration: Gold, blue, and magenta dentelle initials throughout; guides for the insertion of miniatures written in lower margins of the verso of the preceding folio; that on fol. 18v indicates a miniature of Saint John the Evangelist, now lacking.

Origin: Written and decorated in Bruges, approximately 1455, for the English market as indicated by the phrase, "secundum consuetudiem Anglie" in fol. 36r. Saints and selections of texts are typically English. Texts 11, 12, 14, and 20 in masculine form.
Saenger, P. Catalogue of pre-1500 western manuscript books,
French and Flemish illuminated manuscripts from Chicago collections,
Siècle d'or de la miniature flamande (exhibition catalogue; Brussels, 1959),
Former owners: William Gonstone and Thomas Mildmay.

Former owner's inscription: "The namys of the children of Wilham Gonstone and Benet his wif of the perisshe of Saincte Donistones in the est as hereafter ffolowith"; list on flyleaf i, first entry: "Friday the xxiiii day of November being Saincte Clementis Day and the xxiiii yere of King Henry VIIthe ...", last entry written in the "Sixt yere of our sayde souuerayne lorde King Henry the Eight."
Former owner's inscription listing the children of Tomas Mildmay; births recorded in various hands to 1607 including the name of Walter Mildmaye.
Heraldic ownership mark drawn in pen in lower margin of fol. 8r, possibly that of Mildmaye.
Stubbs following fol. 166 indicate traces of other ownership notes, now removed.
Erasures, maskings, and scratching out of references to Thomas à Becket and indulgences date from English Reformation.
Ownship attributed to Baron Fitzwalter (-1608) by Kessler, French and Flemish illuminated manuscripts from Chicago collections, not confirmable from the manuscript.

Binding: 15th century dark brown calf, stamped with the same panel four times, front and back incorporating the motto Sancta Maria Mat[er] and with another smaller panel including a griffin, Margaret coming out of the dragon , a wyvern, a stag, a mermaid, an Agnus Dei, a unicorn, a lion, and a monkey.
Cataloged from existing description: Saenger, P.  Cat. of pre-1500 western manuscript books.
